thread.title: Rohingya aid ship to go to Chittagong again - Nation | The Star Online
thread.title_full: Rohingya aid ship to go to Chittagong again - Nation | The Star Online

author: Patrick Leeandshahrul Nazrin Rezal
title: Rohingya aid ship to go to Chittagong again - Nation | The Star Online
text:
Monday, 13 February 2017 | MYT 7:13 PM Rohingya aid ship to go to Chittagong again by patrick lee and shahrul nazrin rezal 
BAY OF BENGAL: The Rohingya aid ship will be going to Chittagong after all, despite earlier plans for it to unload its cargo near Cox's Bazar. 
Aid mission organiser co-chief Datuk Seri Abdul Azeez Abdul Rahim said he was shocked by the sudden change in plans from the Bangladesh government. 
"They asked us to disembark here and they said we're going to anchor here and they were going to send us a barge and discharge all our aid and all of us would get the approval from Bangladeshi immigration. Suddenly they said no, this is the latest," he said. 
Azeez - who spoke to reporters in a meeting room near the Nautical Aliya's bridge - however thanked the Bangladesh government for allowing the ship to dock at Chittagong. 
The Nautical Aliya is carrying some 2,100 tonnes of aid cargo for Rohingya refugees, and it was originally allowed to go to Chittagong after initial plans to go to Teknaf were denied. 
However at about 10am on Monday, the ship was directed to anchor about 6km from Cox's Bazar, where it was visited by a Navy captain. 
Azeez said some of the organisers went over to the Navy ship for a further meeting on the matter that would last some three hours. 
However, a call from Dhaka to the Navy ship informed them of the change in plans, prompting the change to Chittagong in spite of a message from Prime Minister Datuk Seri Najib Tun Razak received by Azeez which said that Chittagong's port was too crowded. 
"This is not a normal mission. This is not business as usual," Azeez said when asked why Bangladesh would change its plans. 
He added that negotiations between the two countries were "healthy", and said that though Chittagong was busy, the ship would be getting a "special route" to dock there. 
Azeez also said that the seas in the area near Cox's Bazar area were rough. 
"God willing," he said, when asked if the mission would still end on the 18th as he had previously claimed. 
When asked if the mission would be delayed, he said that the plan was for Chittagong and that the organisers had not cancelled logistics. 
It is not known whether all of the ship's volunteers would have the necessary visa approvals to get off on land in Bangladesh and to visit the Rohingya camps there. 
The Nautical Aliya is expected to reach Chittagong's port at about 11pm Monday. 
Chittagong is some 140km from Cox's Bazar, which has Rohingya refugee camps nearby.
